awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Building a Comprehensive Evolutionary History of Flagellate Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
For the first ~300 million years of plant life on land, Earth's flora consisted entirely of flagellate plants, which today include approximately 30,000 species of bryophytes, lycophytes, ferns, and gymnosperms. Numerous major innovations, including stomata, vascular tissue, roots and leaves, woody stems, and seeds, evolved first in flagellate plant ancestors. The flagellate plants not only provide a window to the early evolution of these critical features, but are represented today by vibrant and diverse lineages that contribute substantially to global ecology, particularly via contributions to global carbon and nitrogen cycles and offering critical habitats for biodiversity. This research project will analyze molecular genetic variation among the 18,000 available flagellate plant species in order to create a species-level phylogeny (evolutionary tree of species relationships) for the entire group. Phylogenetic trees generated will be linked to fossil data, a comprehensive dataset of plant traits, and available data on species occurrence on the planet. The results of this project will inform investigations into the origins of features characteristic of flowering plants and provide a platform for student training and outreach.

This project will improve our understanding of the history and relationships of the flagellate plants by using new sequencing technologies to examine 500 nuclear loci and to produce a species-level phylogeny for these taxa that is linked to and integrated with an immense and varied amount of data on fossils, phenomic characters, and geospatial distributions. Phenotypic datasets will utilize a natural language processing tool which will be enhanced and tested to handle large datasets and the geospatial data will allow exploration of world-wide patterns of diversity and endemism. All data will be fully integrated into ongoing projects such as Open Tree of Life and Next Generation Phenomics. Education experts will develop an online educational tool for training the next generation of biodiversity scientists by providing an accessible framework for using the project data in university classrooms while promoting evidence-based teaching practices. A MicroPlants citizen science project will promote scientific literacy and plant awareness in the general public, through museums and schools.

por.por_cntn:
For the first ~300 million years following plants' invasion of land, Earth's terrestrial flora consisted entirely of flagellate plants, or plants having sperm with flagella. Today there approximately 30,000 flagellate land plant species, including the bryophytes, lycophytes, ferns, and gymnosperms. Numerous critically important botanical innovations including stomata, vascular tissue, roots and leaves, lignified stems with secondary growth, and seeds, first emerged in flagellate plant ancestors. Despite their rich evolutionary history and vital roles in almost all ecosystems, flagellate plants are understudied relative to the flowering plants, many of whose features can only be understood in the light of flagellate plant evolution. To address this fundamental gap in our understanding of the phylogeny of life, this project aimed to produce an evolutionary framework for the flagellate plants and generate an immense and varied set of data, analytical tools, and teaching resources for the botanical research community. 

Intellectual Merit - Prior to this project, there were few studies using large-scale genomic datasets to infer relationships among flagellate land plants. We developed a targeted sequence capture approach to generate nuclear sequence data from across flagellate land plants. This is a cost effective and accessible method to obtain such genomic data. The 408 locus probe set developed by this project has successfully generating data using samples with very little DNA and with old, degraded DNA extracted from herbarium specimens. We worked with a global network of taxonomists, herbaria, and botanical gardens to acquire samples from approximately 10,000 flagellate plants, from which we sequence data using targeted capture. These data are now transforming molecular systematic studies of flagellate plant lineages through a number of studies. This project also developed probe sets for targeted capture of the same loci in angiosperms as well as plant algal lineages. Together these probe sets provide a tool kit to enable the generation and assembly of comparative phylogenomic datasets across all plants.

The project also developed numerous freely available tools for phylogenetic data analysis. This includes a data analysis pipeline to transform raw sequence data from targeted capture into alignments for phylogenetic analysis and software tools for phasing individual allele and homeolog sequences from the targeted capture data of polyploid taxa to help infer the parental lineages of plants after whole genome duplications.

The project enhanced the herbarium and tissue collections for gymnosperms at the Florida Museum of Natural History (FLAS). We collected nearly 600 new herbarium specimens of gymnosperms with their corresponding duplicates and tissues. All the vouchers were processed, mounted, digitized, and deposited in the FLAS herbarium, and the images are publicly available and searchable. 

Participants in this project used Natural Language Processing (NLP) approaches to extract phenomic, or physical character, data from taxonomic descriptions of thousands of flagellate plant taxa. The project generated phenotypic character matrices all gymnosperms, and thousands of bryophytes and ferns. We also worked to optimize the performance and implementation of the NLP methods for generating phenotypic datasets. We collaborated with the Planteome project to add many structural terms used to describe flagellate plant structures that have not been previously included in formal ontologies. We also identified thousands of trait terms to be included in the Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO) and contributed to the elaboration of a 'modifier ontology' that includes frequency, certainty, degree, and coverage terms that act as phenotype modifiers. This work will enhance the use of ontologies for questions involving flagellate plants.

Broader Impacts - Education experts developed online tools for training the next generation of biodiversity scientists. The primary educational product developed by this project is the Flagellate Plant Phylogeny Voyager (FPPV; http://flagellateplants.org), an online portal for hosting resources that focus on teaching about flagellate plants, systematic biology, and biodiversity research in general. It features six educational activities for K-12 and higher education. These activities were tested in an undergraduate course at the University of Florida and in a high school environmental science class in Chicago, and the effects of these activities on student learning, STEM attitudes, and perceptions of flagellate plants and their role in society was assessed. All activities were designed and implemented in alignment with curriculum standards such as the Next Generation Science Standards and Common Core State Standards. Each activity is accompanied with an implementation guide for educators and parents. This project produced four manuscripts in peer-reviewed publications on science pedagogical research.

This project organized and hosted symposia, colloquia, or workshops at the International Botanical Congress, Latin American Botanical Congress, Bryophytes, Lichens, and Northern Ecosystems in a Changing World conference, and meetings of the Botanical Society of America and Society of Systematic Biologists. 

Two postdocs, five graduate students, and four undergraduates were trained in natural history research and played active roles in project management. They broadened their personal collaborative networks by participating in the project and communicating with a wide range of scientists.
